title: 107_s434
content: The Act is titled the "Yankton Sioux Tribe and Santee Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purposes section. The "Flood Control Act of 1944" approved the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program for economic development, irrigation, flood protection, and other purposes. The impounded waters for the program have flooded fertile bottom lands along the Missouri River. The Fort Randall and Gavins Point projects, part of the Pick-Sloan program, generate hydropower and impound water, but the Yankton Sioux Tribe and Santee Sioux Tribe reservations remain undeveloped. The United States Army Corps of Engineers took Indian lands for the Fort Randall and Gavins Point projects through condemnation proceedings, denying the Yankton Sioux Tribe and Santee Sioux Tribe compensation for direct damages. The tribes also did not receive just compensation for the taking of productive agricultural lands. The Yankton Sioux Tribe and Santee Sioux Tribe did not receive fair compensation for their land taken for the Fort Randall Dam and Reservoir. The Yankton Sioux Tribe is entitled to $23,023,743 for 2,851.40 acres, and the Santee Sioux Tribe should receive $4,789,010 for 593.10 acres near the Santee village. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. Defines "Indian tribe," "Santee Sioux Tribe," and "Yankton Sioux Tribe." SEC. 4. YANKTON SIOUX TRIBE DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND. Establishment of the Yankton Sioux Tribe Development Trust Fund in the Treasury of the United States to consist of deposited amounts. Funding includes a specific initial deposit and additional interest accrued on that amount. The Yankton Sioux Tribe Development Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States with specific initial deposit and interest accrual. The Secretary of the Treasury is responsible for investing the Fund and depositing resulting interest back into it. Withdrawal of interest begins on the 11th fiscal year after enactment of the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers interest from the Fund to the Secretary of the Interior for payments to the Yankton Sioux Tribe as requested. Payments can only be made after the tribe adopts a tribal plan. The Yankton Sioux Tribe must use payments for projects and programs outlined in their tribal plan. The Treasury Secretary cannot transfer or withdraw funds deposited, except in specific circumstances. SEC. 5. SANTEE SIOUX TRIBE DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND. Establishment of the "Santee Sioux Tribe Development Trust Fund" in the Treasury of the United States to consist of deposited amounts under the Act. On the 11th fiscal year after enactment, the Secretary of the Treasury will deposit $4,789,010 from the General Fund, along with additional interest accrued on the deposited amount. The Secretary of the Treasury will invest the Trust Fund in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Interest resulting from these investments will be deposited back into the Fund. Starting on the 11th fiscal year after enactment, the Secretary will withdraw the aggregate amount of interest annually. The Secretary of the Treasury will transfer interest from the Trust Fund to the Secretary of the Interior for the Santee Sioux Tribe's use. The transferred amounts have no fiscal year limitation and can only be used for payments to the tribe as requested. Payments can only be made after the tribe adopts a tribal plan. The Santee Sioux Tribe must use payments for projects and programs in their tribal plan. The Treasury Secretary cannot transfer or withdraw deposited amounts, except in specific cases. SEC. 6. TRIBAL PLANS. The tribal council of the Yankton Sioux and Santee Sioux Tribes must prepare a tribal plan within 24 months of this Act. The plan should outline how payments under section 4(d) or 5(d) will be used for economic and infrastructure development, as well as for educational, health, recreational, and social welfare purposes. The plan can also include a combination of these activities. Each tribal council must provide the tribe with a copy of the tribal plan for review before finalization. The council can update the plan annually with input from tribe members. Consultation with the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Health is required during the planning process. The tribes' activities in carrying out tribal plans are audited annually as part of a single-agency audit required by the Office of Management and Budget circular A-133. Auditors determine if funds were spent in accordance with the tribal plans. The tribes' activities are audited annually to ensure funds are spent according to tribal plans. Written audit findings must be included in tribal council proceedings, and per capita payments are prohibited for members of specific tribes. SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY OF TRIBE FOR PROGRAMS AND SERVICES: Payments to Yankton Sioux Tribe or Santee Sioux Tribe under this Act won't reduce or deny entitled services. Payments are tax-exempt and won't affect power rates. SEC. 8. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION. SEC. 8. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not diminish any water rights of Indian tribes, treaty rights, or authorities of the Secretary of the Interior or other Federal agencies. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds are authorized for the implementation of this Act, including administration of the Yankton Sioux Tribe Development Trust Fund and Santee Sioux Tribe Development Trust Fund. SEC. 10. EXTINGUISHMENT OF CLAIMS. Upon the deposit of funds, all monetary claims by the Yankton Sioux Tribe or the Santee Sioux Tribe of Nebraska against the United States for land loss related to the Fort Randall and Gavins Point projects shall be extinguished.
